Violation_Type: Failure to properly assess refugee claim
Application_Facts: Ms. El Aoudie converted to Christianity in Canada and claimed sur place refugee status, fearing persecution in Morocco due to her religious conversion.
Residency_Compliance: Lawfully present in Canada at time of application
Misrepresentation_Element: RPD alleged potential immigration motive, but no finding of misrepresentation was made by the Court
Procedural_Issue: RPD failed to consider all relevant evidence including baptismal certificate and psychological reports
Evidentiary_Deficiency: RPD did not adequately address documentary and expert evidence supporting authenticity of conversion
Credibility_Assessment: RPD expressed doubt about authenticity of religious conversion due to lack of religious knowledge
Decision_Outcome: RPD initially denied refugee status
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of RPD decision
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of refugee claim by a different RPD panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Person in need of protection under IRPA s. 97
Decision_Rationale: The RPD's assessment was unreasonable because it failed to engage with key evidence supporting the claimant's genuine conversion and resulting risk of persecution

Legal_Issue: Whether the Board failed to assess risk of religious persecution upon return to China
Credibility_Assessment: Board doubted Mr. Huang's knowledge of church activities and circumstances of exit from China
Legal_Provision: Section 96-98 of IRPA regarding refugee determination
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of religious persecution in China
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of credible evidence supporting active church participation
Application_Error: Failure to analyze likelihood of persecution despite doubts about credibility
Evidence_Ignored: Potential risk of persecution based on perceived religious affiliation
Legal_Standard: The Board must assess the objective risk of persecution regardless of past membership if there is a subjective fear
Application_Factor: Country conditions in China regarding religious freedom
Decision_Outcome: Remitted for new hearing before a different panel

Dispute_Type: Credibility of applicant's religious identity and church membership
Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of the Board's credibility finding
Outcome: Board's decision set aside, case remitted for redetermination
Credibility_Assessment: Found lack of credibility due to inconsistencies in church membership numbers and insufficient Christian knowledge
Evidence_Type: Applicant's testimony, claimed church membership, religious knowledge
Legal_Provision: Section 96 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) – Refugee definition
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Perceived inconsistencies in church membership numbers and level of Christian knowledge
Application_Error: Overly microscopic scrutiny of minor inconsistencies
Assessment_Standard: Plausibility and reasonableness of credibility findings
Evidence_Ignored: Contextual explanation for minor discrepancies in religious knowledge and membership details
Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard with high deference to administrative decision-makers
Application_Factor: Applicant's ability to demonstrate genuine religious belief and membership
Decision_Outcome: Original dismissal overturned; claim remitted for new hearing

Dispute_Type: Credibility dispute, Sur place refugee claim
Legal_Issue: Credibility findings, Consideration of sur place claim
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's evidence found implausible regarding relationship, escape, and medical treatment
Evidence_Type: Personal testimony, Medical records, Evidence of activism
Legal_Provision: Section 97 or 98 of IRPA (refugee protection), Section 101(1)(a) or (f) - well-founded fear of persecution
Basis_of_Claim: Persecution for homosexuality, Subsequent claim as a gay rights activist in Canada (sur place)
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of credible evidence supporting relationship, escape, medical treatment, and insufficient proof of activism risking persecution
Decision_Maker: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court
Application_Error: Failure to raise or substantiate sur place claim explicitly, Implausibility in key narrative elements
Legal_Standard: Reasonable apprehension of persecution, Plausibility and consistency of testimony
Decision_Outcome: Dismissal of refugee claim, No error found by Federal Court

Application_Facts: Applicant's age, education, ethnic origin, and baptism evidence were not considered; inappropriate questions about religious practices without specialized knowledge
Procedural_Issue: Failure to reasonably consider all evidence
Inadequate credibility assessment
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to account for subjective and objective factors
Lack of comprehensive context in credibility analysis
Credibility_Assessment: Assessment found unreasonable due to lack of comprehensive analysis
Decision_Outcome: Refugee status denied by Refugee Protection Division
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of the Board's decision
Decision_Rationale: Decision failed to consider all relevant factors and context; credibility assessment was inadequate

Legal_Issue: Validity of IRB's rejection of sur place refugee claim based on conversion to Mormonism
Outcome: IRB's decision overturned, case remanded for reconsideration
Credibility_Assessment: IRB questioned credibility and motives behind conversion
Evidence_Type: Credible evidence of religious activities in host country (Canada)
Basis_of_Claim: Sur place refugee claim due to conversion to Mormonism in Canada
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Risk of persecution for apostasy upon return to Iran
Application_Error: IRB focused on applicant's motives rather than objective risk
Assessment_Standard: Credible evidence of activities must be assessed independently of motive
Evidence_Ignored: Potential persecution risk based on actual or imputed religious change
Legal_Standard: Objective risk of persecution under Convention grounds
Decision_Outcome: Remanded for reconsideration by new panel

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed 1099 days of residency but provided insufficient credible evidence
Misrepresentation_Element: Credibility concerns due to inconsistent contact details, limited employment and financial records
Procedural_Issue: Fair procedures followed by Citizenship Judge
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of sufficient credible documentation supporting residency
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's credibility doubted; explanations not treated as evidence
Decision_Outcome: Appeal dismissed
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of Citizenship Judge's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Burden of proof on applicant to demonstrate residency
Decision_Rationale: Citizenship Judge reasonably concluded applicant did not meet residency requirement due to credibility and evidentiary issues

Violation_Type: Excessive demand on health or social services
Application_Facts: Applicant's son has cerebral palsy; financial plan provided but lacked credible details such as qualified service providers and sufficient coverage for specialized care
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review under IRPA subsection 72(1)
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of specificity, weak assumptions, absence of qualified service providers, insufficient coverage for specialized care
Credibility_Assessment: Plan deemed insufficient and not credible by the court
Decision_Outcome: Inadmissible due to potential excessive demand on health/social services
Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; original decision upheld
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of immigration officer's decision
Remedy_Sought: Overturn inadmissibility finding and allow permanent residence application
Decision_Rationale: Immigration officer's assessment was reasonable given the lack of credible and detailed evidence that the son’s needs would not create excessive demand on health or social services
Authority_Responsible: Immigration officer, Federal Court (on judicial review)

Crimes.Violation_Type: Immigration violation - failure to comply with temporary resident conditions
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 183 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant remained in Canada beyond the authorized period of stay under a temporary resident visa
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Temporary resident who became out of status
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Allegation of procedural unfairness in H&C assessment
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over judicial review of immigration decisions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible evidence supporting risk as a Jewish person in Ukraine
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer found applicant's claims lacked credibility and supporting documentation
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Overturning of immigration officer’s decision via judicial review
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Humanitarian and Compassionate considerations under section 25(1) of IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Applicant demonstrated integration but showed disregard for immigration laws; no exceptional circumstances established
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration Officer, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work without authorization under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 186 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant engaged in employment in Canada without proper work authorization while on a temporary visa
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Fairness in assessment of H&C application following inadmissibility
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court review of immigration officer's H&C decision
Evidence_Used: Nature and duration of unauthorized work
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient credible evidence to substantiate risks in country of origin
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer questioned credibility of applicant's claims regarding hardship and risk
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: H&C application denied due to lack of exceptional circumstances
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review dismissed - decision found reasonable
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Court intervention to overturn administrative decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Section 25(1) of IRPA - Humanitarian and Compassionate grounds
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Establishment in Canada outweighed by non-compliance with immigration laws; no compelling H&C factors identified
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration Officer, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC)

Legal_Provision_Violated: Subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Father's death; family seeking permanent residence; child's best interests central to H&C application; return to Guyana would impact child
Claimant_Status: Applicant for permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Residency_Compliance: Compliant with immigration status prior to refusal
Procedural_Issue: Officer applied incorrect legal test by requiring 'unusual and undeserved' or 'disproportionate' hardship instead of treating best interests of the child as a primary consideration
Evidence_Used: Impact of father's death, conditions in Guyana, child's ties to Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to adequately consider evidence regarding child's best interests
Decision_Outcome: Refusal of permanent residence application based on insufficient H&C grounds
Relief_Sought: Allowance of permanent residence application on H&C grounds
Remedy_Sought: Remission of case to a different decision-maker for reconsideration
Legal_Standard_Applied: Best interests of the child must be a primary consideration in H&C applications
Decision_Rationale: Officer unreasonably elevated the threshold for hardship; failed to properly apply the best interests of the child as required by law
Authority_Responsible: Immigration Officer at Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Violation_Type: Failure to provide adequate state protection
Legal_Provision_Violated: subparagraph 97(1)(b)(i) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant experienced past sexual abuse; lacks family support in Saint Vincent and the Grenadines; faces risk if returned
Procedural_Issue: Panel failed to consider unique circumstances; selective use of evidence
Evidence_Used: Evidence of past abuse, lack of family support, country condition reports on Saint Vincent and the Grenadines
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Ignored negative aspects of state protection; incomplete assessment of applicant's vulnerability
Decision_Outcome: Panel initially denied protection
Outcome: Judicial review granted; decision set aside
Relief_Sought: Recognition as person in need of protection
Remedy_Sought: Remand for fresh determination by a new Panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Person is in need of protection under IRPA if unable or unwilling to avail themselves of their country’s protection due to risk
Decision_Rationale: Panel’s decision was unreasonable due to failure to properly assess state protection and individual circumstances

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the PRRA officer err in assessing evidence regarding hardship and persecution risks?
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Contradictions in evidence undermined credibility
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Claimed religious persecution, integration difficulties, family ties
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Hardship if required to apply for permanent resident visa outside Canada, risk of persecution in Iran
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of new or convincing evidence, inconsistencies in claims
Crimes.Application_Error: Alleged misrepresentation in evaluating risks and integration
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None found; officer considered all relevant factors
Crimes.Application_Factor: Integration into Canadian society, family ties, religious persecution risk
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Not explicitly alleged, but misrepresentation in application

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with visa requirements
Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to meet visa application requirements abroad
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Sections 11, 25, and 113 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant claimed persecution risks and lack of integration in home country
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Permanent Resident applicant under H&C consideration
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Applicant residing in Canada without valid permanent residency
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Not central, but insufficient proof affected assessment
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Request for exemption from out-of-country visa application
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority to grant humanitarian and compassionate relief
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Claims of religious persecution, integration challenges
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of hardship or religious conversion
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Contradictions in evidence reduced credibility
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Exemption from applying for visa outside Canada
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No error in assessment of hardship or integration factors

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the officer err in assessing hardship and persecution claims?
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Contradictions in evidence and lack of new proof
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Claims of religious and political persecution, integration in Canada
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Risk of persecution in Iran and strong ties to Canada
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of credible evidence supporting claims
Crimes.Application_Error: Alleged failure to properly assess persecution risk and integration
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None identified; officer assessed all factors reasonably
Crimes.Application_Factor: Family ties, duration of stay, religious beliefs
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Use of forged documents for entry into Canada

Violation_Type: Denial of deferral request for removal
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 48 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant requested deferral due to pregnant wife's medical complications
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of administrative decision
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence that applicant was essential for care
Decision_Outcome: Deferral request denied
Relief_Sought: Deferral of removal
Decision_Rationale: No live controversy remains; decision within acceptable range of outcomes

Application_Facts: Applicant fled Mexico due to threats and assaults after reporting a drug transaction; reported incidents to authorities but received no protection
Procedural_Issue: Board Member incorrectly applied the legal standard by focusing on Mexico’s efforts rather than actual effectiveness of protection
Evidence_Used: Applicant's testimony, reports of threats and assaults, lack of response from Mexican authorities
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to assess effectiveness of state protection in Mexico
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected by Board Member
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decision set aside
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a refugee in Canada
Remedy_Sought: Re-determination of refugee claim by a different Board Member
Legal_Standard_Applied: Balance of probabilities; adequacy and effectiveness of state protection
Decision_Rationale: Board failed to properly assess whether state protection was actually effective in Mexico; focus should be on effectiveness, not just existence of efforts
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Protection Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board

Violation_Type: Failure to distinguish persecution from discrimination
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, SC 2001, c 27
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, SC 2001, c 27
Application_Facts: Applicants are Roma citizens of Hungary who claimed persecution and lack of state protection in their home country; sought refugee status in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Errors in credibility assessments
Failure to properly evaluate key incidents
Inadequate reasoning on state protection
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Key incidents dismissed or not properly evaluated
Reliance on unreliable credibility determinations
Credibility_Assessment: Board made unreasonable credibility findings
Failed to provide sufficient reasons for disbelieving claimants
Decision_Outcome: Board denied refugee status
Outcome: Federal Court allowed the application, set aside the Board's decision
Relief_Sought: Recognition of refugee status
Reassessment of claim
Remedy_Sought: Re-examination of claims by a differently constituted Board
Decision_Rationale: Board's decision was unreasonable due to flawed credibility analysis, misapplication of persecution standard, and inadequate assessment of state protection
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Violation_Type: Refusal of exemption from immigrant visa requirements
Application_Facts: Applicants argued procedural unfairness due to unaddressed documents and incorrect assessment of children's best interests
Procedural_Issue: Alleged failure to address all submitted documents
Assessment of procedural fairness
Evidence_Used: Documents submitted by applicants regarding humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Decision_Outcome: Officer's decision found to be reasonable and procedurally fair
Relief_Sought: Certification of general importance
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of immigration officer's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds under IRPA s.25(1)
Decision_Rationale: Officer considered all relevant evidence and applied the correct legal test

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 34(1)(f) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant alleged ties with MQM-A, an organization deemed to engage in terrorism
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of immigration officer's decision
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Amnesty International and Jane's World reports considered credible; SATP report given little weight
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Sufficient credible evidence from reputable sources established reasonable grounds to believe MQM-A engaged in terrorism

Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Potential threat due to association with MQM-A
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: MQM-A engaged in violent acts for political purposes
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Membership in or support of a violent organization
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Violent acts by MQM-A members for political objectives
Crimes.Target_Entity: Civilians and state institutions in Pakistan
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: High for Amnesty International and Jane's World; low for SATP
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Amnesty and Jane's World deemed reliable; SATP not
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Cited: Section 34(1)(f) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Inadmissibility to Canada, denial of refugee protection

Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Association with a proscribed terrorist organization
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: MQM-A classified as engaging in terrorism
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Political violence including assassinations, bombings, and targeted attacks
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: High for Amnesty and Jane's World; Dr. Rizvi's statement considered but less persuasive
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Official reports favored over individual statements
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Cited: Section 34(1)(f) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Terrorism-related inadmissibility based on organizational membership
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Permanent inadmissibility, no right to appeal, potential removal

Legal_Issue: Did the Board err in failing to consider the applicant's membership in a particular social group (women in Haiti who have been raped)?
Governing_Law: The Board must consider all grounds for claiming refugee status, even if not explicitly raised by the claimant.
Outcome: The Board erred by not considering the central ground of the claim; the case is remanded for redetermination.
Basis_of_Claim: Gender-based persecution as a member of a particular social group (women in Haiti who have been raped)
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to analyze gender-based persecution claim
Application_Error: Failure to address central claim of gender-based persecution
Evidence_Ignored: Claim of rape and fear of persecution in Haiti
Legal_Standard: Duty to consider all grounds for refugee status
Application_Factor: Applicant entered US with false passport, later sought refugee status in Canada due to fear of persecution in Haiti
Decision_Outcome: Judicial review allowed; case remanded for redetermination by a different panel

Governing_Law: The Board must consider all grounds for claiming refugee status, even if not explicitly raised by the claimant. The decision must be reasonable, transparent, and intelligible.
Application_Facts: Applicant fled Haiti after being raped and claimed refugee status in Canada, citing fear of persecution as part of a specific social group.
Residency_Compliance: Failed to comply with visa conditions by overstaying
Procedural_Issue: Board failed to analyze gender-based persecution claim despite explicit raising
Evidence_Used: Testimony regarding rape and fear of return to Haiti
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of analysis on key evidence related to gender-based persecution
Decision_Outcome: Application for judicial review allowed; matter remanded for redetermination by a different panel
Relief_Sought: Refugee status based on membership in a particular social group
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of refugee claim with proper consideration of gender-based persecution
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness, transparency, and intelligibility of decision
Decision_Rationale: Board’s failure to address central claim rendered decision unsubstantiated

Crimes.Application_Facts: Male applicant previously deported from the USA returned without authorization
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Lack of lawful entry or status documentation
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: U.S. conviction and deportation affecting Canadian refugee claim
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No proof of legal re-entry or relief from inadmissibility
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not directly challenged, but claim undermined by criminal history
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of Refugee Protection Division decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious non-political crime under Article 1F(b) of the Refugee Convention
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Prior conviction and illegal re-entry demonstrate criminal conduct incompatible with refugee protection
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Federal Court on review

Crimes.Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act violations
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee eligibility and exclusion under IRPA
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Application of Article 1F(b) exclusion for serious non-political crime
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Refugee Convention
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of Refugee Protection Division decision
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Assessment of male applicant’s drug trafficking conviction and female applicant’s lack of evidence for persecution claims
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to establish well-founded fear and rebut exclusion grounds
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Female applicant returned to country of origin, undermining subjective fear
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Article 1F(b) excludes individuals convicted of serious non-political crimes
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution by Colombian groups
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Conviction records, return to Colombia, lack of documentary threats
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Applicants argued fear of persecution despite criminal history
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Overturn of IRB decision through judicial review

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of cocaine for the purpose of trafficking
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Exclusion from refugee status under Article 1F(b)
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether drug trafficking constitutes a serious non-political crime
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of Refugee Protection Division decision
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Conviction for possession with intent to distribute, sentence served, fair trial confirmed
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Applicant failed to rebut presumption of seriousness
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Article 1F(b) exclusion applies to serious non-political crimes regardless of political motivation
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Claim of persecution fear despite criminal record
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: U.S. conviction, 27-month sentence, deportation, gravity of offense in Canada
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Applicant did not present mitigating factors
Crimes.Authority: Refugee Protection Division, Federal Court on review

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Exclusion from refugee protection based on criminal conduct
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Fair hearing confirmed; no breach found
Crimes.Mode_of_Entry: Illegal re-entry into the USA following deportation
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: Convicted of drug conspiracy in the USA
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Criminal activity unrelated to political persecution
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Seriousness of drug-related conspiracy and lack of mitigation

Application_Facts: RPD doubted authenticity of applicant's documents without sufficient evidence
Misrepresentation_Element: Unsupported suspicions about Chinese document fraud
Assumption of specialized knowledge about Hukou features
Misinterpretation of forensic analysis of marriage certificate
Improper linking of document irregularities to overall credibility
Procedural_Issue: Decision based on speculative and extraneous factors
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible evidence to support document fraud claims
Unsubstantiated assumptions about Hukou
Credibility_Assessment: RPD questioned applicant's credibility based on flawed document analysis
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected due to lack of credibility and document irregularities
Outcome: Decision set aside, case referred for redetermination by a different panel
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of RPD decision
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of RPD decision and redetermination
Decision_Rationale: RPD's findings were speculative, lacked evidentiary support, and involved errors in credibility assessment

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of rejecting refugee claim based on alleged fraudulent documents
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected due to alleged fraudulent identity documents
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish credibility and authenticity of documents
Credibility_Factor: RPD improperly linked document irregularities to overall credibility
Legal_Rule: Decision must be based on credible evidence, not speculation
Remedy_Requested: Overturn RPD decision and remit for redetermination
Outcome: Decision overturned, case remanded to a different panel
Legal_Provision: IRPA provisions on refugee protection and credibility assessment

Application_Facts: Respondent was absent for 630 days, falling short of the 1095-day physical presence requirement in the four years preceding the application
Procedural_Issue: Citizenship Judge's reasons were inadequate and failed to address key evidence gaps
Evidence_Used: Family presence in Canada, property ownership, community involvement
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of documentation on physical presence and financial ties to Canada
Decision_Outcome: Appeal allowed
Relief_Sought: Review of approval of citizenship application
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of the Citizenship Judge's decision
Decision_Rationale: Respondent did not meet the 1095-day physical presence requirement under any of the three legal tests; insufficient evidence and inadequate reasoning by the Citizenship Judge

Crimes.Application_Facts: Mr. Samuel overstayed his visa in Canada.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Applicant for permanent residence or work permit
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Discrepancies between application and FOSS notes used to question credibility
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Board failed to raise issues during hearing, violating procedural fairness
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority of the Immigration Appeal Division to assess character based on pardoned convictions
Crimes.Evidence_Used: FOSS notes, application forms, police reports
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Reliance on unverified police reports and incorrect factual assertions (e.g., son's birth year)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative assessment based on inconsistencies and omissions
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Visa denied due to character concerns
Crimes.Outcome: Decision set aside on judicial review
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Section 5 of the Criminal Records Act; procedural fairness
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Improper reliance on pardoned convictions and failure to disclose key issues

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Use of pardoned convictions and unproven allegations to impugn character
Crimes.Governing_Law: Criminal Records Act, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Outcome: Decision dismissed due to procedural unfairness
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Assessed as lacking credibility due to inconsistencies in statements
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Police reports, application forms, FOSS notes
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 5 of the Criminal Records Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: False statements and omissions in immigration application
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to notify applicant of issues affecting decision
Crimes.Application_Error: Omissions and discrepancies in application versus official records
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Procedural fairness and reliability of evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Pardon under Section 5 of the Criminal Records Act
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Adverse characterization of pardoned offenses is prohibited
Crimes.Application_Factor: Inconsistencies between Mr. Samuel's account and documentation

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Work permit eligibility and character assessment
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reliance on pardoned convictions and unverified police reports
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, Criminal Records Act
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Perceived lack of remorse due to false statements and non-testification
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Police reports, application data, internal notes
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 5 of the Criminal Records Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Past convictions and alleged false statements despite pardon
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Use of erroneous facts (son’s birth year) and unverified reports
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Procedural fairness and admissibility of evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Pardoned convictions cannot negatively affect character assessment
Crimes.Application_Factor: Failure to disclose relevant issues during hearing

Crimes.Crime_Name: False Statements in Application for Permanent Residence
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness in using application omissions against applicant
Crimes.Governing_Law: Criminal Records Act, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: FOSS notes and application discrepancies used without disclosure
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Section 5 of the Criminal Records Act prohibits adverse use of pardons
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Violation of procedural fairness and misuse of pardoned record
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Decision found unreasonable and set aside
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Not applicable – government body did not respond adequately to procedural flaws
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 5 of the Criminal Records Act

Crimes.Perpetrator_Type: Non-Canadian spouse with prior deportation history
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: Moderate to high due to nature of offense and re-entry attempt
Crimes.Risk_Type: Public safety and family unit integrity
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient due to reliance on untested police reports
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Police reports, application statements, FOSS notes
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Low – police reports not corroborated by testimony
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative – based on failure to testify and inconsistent accounts
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: Not applicable – focus on immigration consequences
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 5 of the Criminal Records Act, IRPA provisions on criminal inadmissibility

Application_Facts: Ms. Ryan was absent for 1,136 days during the four-year period preceding her application, resulting in only 324 days of physical presence in Canada
Residency_Compliance: No – only 324 days of residence, falling short of the required 1,095 days
Procedural_Issue: Citizenship Judge applied a qualitative test instead of strictly assessing physical presence
Evidence_Used: Record of absences, evidence of ties to Canada, illness-related reasons for absence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient documentation or justification to offset prolonged absence under statutory requirements
Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; focus was on legal interpretation rather than credibility
Decision_Outcome: Citizenship approval by Citizenship Judge
Relief_Sought: Review of Citizenship Judge's decision
Remedy_Sought: Setting aside the decision and denying citizenship based on non-compliance
Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation of 'residence' as physical presence with limited exceptions
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship Judge's interpretation fell outside acceptable outcomes by allowing qualitative factors to override clear statutory residency requirements

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Legal_Provision_Involved: Section 9 of the Crown Liability and Proceedings Act
Outcome: Motion to strike denied except for 'wrongfully' in termination allegation
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged negligence and breach of fiduciary duty by the Crown post-deployment

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 9 of the Crown Liability and Proceedings Act
Application_Facts: Injuries during and after deployment; inadequate medical care, poisoning, failure to inform
Claimant_Status: Military veteran receiving pension for service-related injuries

Victim_Status: Military veteran with service-related health issues
Evidence_Sufficiency: Not plain and obvious that injuries were covered by pension or statutorily barred

Dispute_Type: Claim for additional damages beyond pension
Legal_Issue: Scope of statutory bars under Pension Act and Crown Liability and Proceedings Act
Governing_Law: Section 9 of the Crown Liability and Proceedings Act
Procedural_Stage: Motion to strike under Rule 221(1)(a) of the Federal Court Rules
Remedy_Requested: Damages for poisoning, lack of medical support, misinformation post-discharge

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 96 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Respondent was a Tamil passenger on the MV Sun Sea claiming fear of persecution
Procedural_Issue: RPD failed to provide sufficient legal rationale or factual findings linking social group to persecution
Evidence_Used: Passenger status on MV Sun Sea, claimed risk due to Tamil ethnicity
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of connection between social group and human rights or discrimination considerations
Decision_Outcome: RPD decision found unreasonable
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a refugee based on persecution risk
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration by a different RPD panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Membership in a particular social group under section 96
Decision_Rationale: Failure to establish nexus between social group or political opinion and persecution with adequate legal and factual basis

Application_Facts: Mr. Nagulesan submitted corroborative evidence after the hearing but before the decision was made; the RPD did not consider it despite proper submission procedures being followed.
Procedural_Issue: RPD failed to consider additional evidence submitted post-hearing, breaching duty of fairness
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to consider relevant corroborative evidence impacted credibility assessment
Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility finding due in part to exclusion of new evidence
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected due to lack of credibility and insufficient evidence
Outcome: Federal Court allowed judicial review; RPD decision set aside
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of RPD decision
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of refugee claim by a different panel
Decision_Rationale: The RPD had a duty to consider properly submitted post-hearing evidence under Rule 37; failure to do so rendered the process unfair

Legal_Issue: Whether the IRB's decision to deny refugee status due to lack of credibility was reasonable and justified
Governing_Law: Canada's Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Outcome: IRB's decision upheld, judicial review dismissed
Credibility_Assessment: Inconsistent testimony, implausible statements, lack of detailed knowledge
Legal_Provision: Requirement to demonstrate credible fear of persecution
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Credibility of applicant, failure to seek asylum in U.S. for three years
Legal_Standard: Credible fear of persecution, consistency and plausibility of testimony
Decision_Outcome: Refugee status not granted

Legal_Issue: Whether the tribunal erred in dismissing the complaint regarding the use of a retracted reference
Evidence_Assessment: The tribunal found no evidence of unreliability or bias in the retracted reference
Decision_Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate unreasonable decision-making
Credibility_Factor: Mr. Burke's retracted reference was assessed for reliability and bias
Legal_Rule: The tribunal must determine if the reference is sufficiently familiar with the candidate's work; abuse of authority includes bad faith or personal favoritism
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged abuse of authority due to reliance on a retracted reference
Authority: Attorney General of Canada (named as sole respondent)

Legal_Issue: Whether the citizenship judge's decision adequately explained how the residence requirement was met
Evidence_Assessment: Contradictions in evidence regarding residency were not addressed
Decision_Outcome: Original decision set aside due to inadequate reasoning
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate compliance with residence requirements
Legal_Rule: Standard of review for adequacy of reasons is correctness; determination of residence compliance is reviewed under reasonableness standard
Standard_of_Review: Correctness for adequacy of reasons; reasonableness for residence determination
Grounds_for_Claim: Insufficient reasoning by citizenship judge, failure to apply clear residency test
Outcome_on_Merits: Decision referred to another judge for redetermination
Key_Evidence_Considered: Applicant's continued residence in France since 2005 while holding permanent resident status in Canada
Legal_Framework: Canadian Citizenship Act, residency requirements for naturalization
Defendant_Response: Baron did not appear or defend the application
Evidence_Type: Residency records, application documents, judicial findings
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review sought by the Crown
Outcome: Original decision annulled, case remanded for reconsideration
Legal_Provision: Residence requirement under Canadian citizenship law

Crime_Name: Deportation of a Bisexual Individual to Potential Harm
Dispute_Type: Whether removal to Nigeria poses risk due to sexual orientation
Legal_Issue: Can the removal be stayed based on potential harm due to sexual orientation?
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review application with motion for stay
Evidence_Assessment: Credible evidence of increased risks for LGBTQ+ individuals in Nigeria post-decision
Decision_Outcome: Motion for stay granted
Burden_of_Proof: Applicant must show serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, and favorable balance of convenience
Credibility_Factor: Officer incorrectly deemed risk unchanged; applicant's fear considered credible
Legal_Rule: Tripartite test: serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness, depending on context of administrative decision
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution due to sexual orientation and worsening conditions in Nigeria
Outcome_on_Merits: Stay of removal ordered until underlying application is resolved
Key_Evidence_Considered: Conditions for LGBTQ+ individuals in Nigeria, post-decision developments, personal circumstances of Mr. Abioye
Legal_Framework: Federal Court jurisdiction, immigration and refugee protection laws
Defendant_Response: Risk assessment deemed unchanged by the Officer
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, country condition reports, personal testimony
Remedy_Requested: Stay of removal pending resolution of judicial review
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, relevant sections on risk assessment and stay of removal

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of RPD's decision on 'sur place' refugee claim
Outcome: Application allowed, decision set aside, remanded for reconsideration
Basis_of_Claim: Risk upon return to country of origin ('sur place' claim)
Key_Factor_in_Determination: RPD's failure to consider evidence of risk for Tamils returning from MV Sun Sea
Application_Error: Failure to assess relevant evidence in 'sur place' analysis
Evidence_Ignored: Amnesty International reports indicating risks for returned Tamil individuals
Application_Factor: Nature of prior persecution or risk
Decision_Outcome: Remanded to a new RPD panel for re-evaluation

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Exclusion under Article 1F(b) of the UN Refugee Convention
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: CRDD found Mr. Liang's story implausible
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Implausibility of claim and preference for Minister's version
Crimes.Application_Factor: Use of fraudulent documents to enter Canada

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Knowledge and intent in possession of false documents
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: CRDD did not explicitly assess intent
Crimes.Application_Factor: Use of fraudulent passport to enter Canada

Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Flight risk and danger to public
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Considered sufficient for exclusion under Article 1F(b)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Liang’s claims deemed less credible

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee exclusion based on criminal involvement
Crimes.Mode_of_Entry: Through investor program with fraudulent passport
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Serious reasons for considering criminal involvement

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee exclusion based on leadership role

Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Expert testimony on forgery given little weight
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On Minister to show serious reasons

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee exclusion due to corruption charges
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Liang fled China; state action deemed legitimate

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Inadmissibility based on alleged membership in a terrorist organization
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 34(1)(f) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Mr. Naeem, a former member of MQM-A, applied for permanent residence; his application was denied due to alleged ties to terrorism.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Officer's decision lacked clarity and adequate reasoning; Minister failed to consider national interest guidelines
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Membership in MQM-A and its alleged involvement in terrorism between 1988–1999
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to define 'terrorism' or link specific acts by MQM-A to legal definition
Crimes.Outcome: Decision set aside; case remitted for reconsideration
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of inadmissibility and ministerial refusal
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Overturning of decisions and right to reapply
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness for officer’s decision; patent unreasonableness for Minister’s refusal
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Lack of sufficient reasoning on defining terrorism and failure to assess national interest
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration officer and the Minister of Immigration

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration inadmissibility based on organizational affiliation
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether membership in MQM-A constitutes inadmissibility under terrorism provisions
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: MQM-A engaged in violent acts between 1988–1999; Mr. Naeem was more than a mere supporter
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Decision deemed unreasonable due to inadequate reasoning
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On immigration authorities to establish inadmissibility
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Officer did not sufficiently analyze individual role or intent
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Section 34(1)(f): Membership in an organization reasonably believed to engage in terrorism leads to inadmissibility
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Insufficient justification linking membership to terrorism
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Historical activities of MQM-A and nature of Mr. Naeem’s involvement
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review and reinstatement of application
Crimes.Authority: Immigration Division and Minister of Immigration

Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Alleged association with MQM-A, an organization involved in terrorism
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Based on past conduct of MQM-A, not direct acts by Mr. Naeem
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Potential risk due to organizational ties
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Violent political activities between 1988–1999 attributed to MQM-A
Crimes.Target_Entity: Civilians and state institutions in Pakistan
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Membership acknowledged, but no direct engagement in violent acts proven
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Failure to define 'terrorism' or connect specific acts to legal standard
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Incomplete assessment of individual culpability
Crimes.Credibility_Factors: Lack of personal admission or direct participation evidence
Crimes.Standard_of_Proof: Reasonable belief standard under administrative law
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Denial of permanent residence and need for judicial intervention

Legal_Issue: Can the applicant obtain a judicial stay of removal based on humanitarian and compassionate grounds?
Outcome: The motion for a stay of removal is dismissed
Credibility_Assessment: Her allegations of irreparable harm were not credible or new
the applicant's claims were previously dismissed as not credible
Key_Factor_in_Determination: lack of credible evidence of irreparable harm
Legal_Standard: Tripartite test: serious issue, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Application_Factor: alleged risks upon return to Hungary
Decision_Outcome: Stay of removal dismissed

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with immigration laws
Application_Facts: Applicant sought H&C consideration after rejected refugee and PRRA claims
Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged risks and hardship deemed not credible
Procedural_Issue: Seeking H&C relief after exhaustion of appeals
Evidence_Used: Prior RPD, PRRA, and H&C decisions
Evidentiary_Deficiency: No new evidence provided
claims not supported by sufficient proof
Credibility_Assessment: Allegations not credible
no new or compelling information
Decision_Outcome: Motion for stay dismissed
Relief_Sought: Stay of removal
Legal_Standard_Applied: Unusual and undeserved or disproportionate hardship
Decision_Rationale: No evidence of unusual hardship; integrity of immigration system favored enforcement

Mitigating_Factors: claimed risks in country of return
Risk_Assessment: Risk upon return to Hungary claimed but not substantiated
Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient evidence of unusual hardship or credible risk
Credibility_Assessment: Risks and hardship not found credible

Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer made a reviewable error in assessing humanitarian and compassionate grounds, particularly considering the best interests of the child
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 25(1)
Outcome: The court dismissed the application for judicial review
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's mother failed to declare him initially
Legal_Provision: s. 25(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds, best interests of the child
Key_Factor_in_Determination: No unusual hardship demonstrated to justify exemption
Application_Error: Failure to declare applicant during initial immigration process
Decision_Outcome: Denial of application under normal criteria; no reviewable error found
Document_Fraud: Omission of declaring the applicant in family class sponsorship

Crime_Name: Trafficking in Contraband in a Penitentiary
Legal_Issue: Did CSC meet its obligations under statute and common law to disclose facts and reasons for reclassification and transfer?
Governing_Law: Subsection 27(1) of the Corrections and Conditional Release Act
Evidence_Assessment: Summaries of intercepted communications and allegations were provided; informant identities withheld
Decision_Outcome: CSC met disclosure obligations; Warden's decision was procedurally fair and reasonable
Legal_Rule: Subsection 27(1) requires disclosure of all information or a summary before decision-making, except when subsection 27(3) applies
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged failure to disclose full information regarding reclassification and transfer
Key_Evidence_Considered: Intercepted communications summaries, allegations, applicant’s rebuttal
Defendant_Response: Applicant confirmed knowledge of disclosed information
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of reclassification and transfer decision
Legal_Provision: Subsection 27(1) and (3) of the Corrections and Conditional Release Act

Violation_Type: Failure to comply with institutional rules related to contraband smuggling allegations
Legal_Provision_Violated: Institutional rules under the Corrections and Conditional Release Act
Governing_Law: Subsection 27(1) of the Corrections and Conditional Release Act
Application_Facts: Inmate was informed of intercepted communications and allegations but not informant identities
Claimant_Status: Inmate seeking reclassification and transfer review
Procedural_Issue: Adequacy of disclosure in reclassification process
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant understood and could rebut the case based on provided summaries
Decision_Outcome: CSC met disclosure obligations; decision procedurally fair
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of reclassification and transfer
Remedy_Sought: Overturn or review of administrative decision
Decision_Rationale: Summary provided sufficient basis for inmate to respond; informant identities protected under subsection 27(3)

Crime_Name: Possession of Contraband in a Penitentiary
Legal_Issue: Did CSC meet its obligations under statute and common law to disclose facts and reasons for reclassification and transfer?
Governing_Law: Subsection 27(1) of the Corrections and Conditional Release Act
Evidence_Assessment: Summaries of intercepted communications and allegations disclosed; informant identities withheld
Decision_Outcome: CSC met disclosure obligations; Warden's decision was procedurally fair and reasonable
Legal_Rule: Subsection 27(1) requires disclosure of all information or a summary before decision-making, except when subsection 27(3) applies
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged insufficient disclosure in reclassification and transfer
Key_Evidence_Considered: Summaries of intercepted communications, allegations, applicant’s rebuttal
Defendant_Response: Applicant acknowledged receipt of sufficient information to respond
Legal_Provision: Subsection 27(1) and (3) of the Corrections and Conditional Release Act

Legal_Issue: Do the Ponce Uribe brothers qualify as persons in need of protection under section 97(1)(b)(ii) of IRPA?
Outcome: The application for judicial review was granted, and the matter was sent back to the RPD for further analysis.
Basis_of_Claim: Risk to life or cruel and unusual treatment upon removal to Mexico due to targeting by Los Zetas
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Personal nature of the threat, adequacy of state protection, internal flight alternatives
Decision_Maker: RPD (Refugee Protection Division), Federal Court on judicial review
Application_Error: RPD initially deemed the risk as generalized without adequately analyzing the personal nature of the threat
Evidence_Ignored: Specific targeting of the Ponce Uribe brothers due to their business by Los Zetas
Application_Factor: Targeting by Los Zetas due to business suitability for gang operations
Decision_Outcome: Remanded for reconsideration with focus on personal risk, state protection, and internal flight alternative

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of immigration inadmissibility assessment
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of CBSA's preliminary assessment of inadmissibility on security grounds
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: CBSA failed to assess Galloway's intent behind aid delivery
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Humanitarian nature of aid, lack of intent to support terrorism
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged support for Hamas through humanitarian aid
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of analysis of donor's purpose or intent
Crimes.Application_Error: Overreach in interpreting facts and law without sufficient basis
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Intent and actual use of humanitarian aid
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonable grounds to believe, more than suspicion but less than balance of probabilities
Crimes.Application_Factor: Delivery of aid to Gaza under Hamas control
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Application dismissed due to absence of final reviewable decision

Crimes.Crime_Name: Providing material support to a terrorist organization
Crimes.National_Security_Element: Alleged support to Hamas, a listed terrorist entity
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Potential enhancement of terrorist activities through material support
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: CBSA's determination of risk based on aid delivery
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Provision of cash and goods to area controlled by terrorist organization
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Voluntary delivery of humanitarian aid (cash and goods)
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Acknowledged delivery of aid, denied terrorist intent
Crimes.Leadership_Role: No evidence of leadership or operational role
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Evidence showed aid was humanitarian and not diverted to terrorism
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Absence of intent to further terrorist objectives
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentation of humanitarian purpose, public statements, aid distribution records
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Galloway's intent assessed as humanitarian, not supportive of terrorism
Crimes.Credibility_Factors: Transparency of aid mission, public nature of delivery
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Attempted exclusion from Canada, blocked speaking tour

Crimes.National_Security_Element: Allegation of membership in Hamas due to aid delivery
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: CBSA’s belief that Galloway may be complicit via support
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Association with a listed terrorist entity despite humanitarian intent
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Delivery of humanitarian aid through Hamas channels
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Acknowledged involvement in aid delivery only
Crimes.Leadership_Role: No indication of leadership or organizational role
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Supporting evidence demonstrated purely humanitarian objectives
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: No evidence of intent to engage in terrorism or organizational membership
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Publicly documented aid mission, recipient use of supplies
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credible assertion of humanitarian purpose
Crimes.Credibility_Factors: Consistent public statements, transparency of actions
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of preliminary inadmissibility finding
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Prevention of entry into Canada for speaking tour

Legal_Issue: Is punishment for illegal exit from Iran and a failed refugee claim considered persecution under the Convention refugee definition?
Outcome: CRDD's decision was overturned, and the case was sent back for reconsideration.
Legal_Provision: Punishment for illegal exit under a law of general application is not persecution unless there is evidence of excessive or extra-judicial punishment.
Basis_of_Claim: Mr. Donboli claimed refugee status due to fear of persecution in Iran based on political opinion and illegal exit.
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Risk of severe or extra-judicial treatment upon return to Iran
Application_Error: CRDD erred by failing to consider if Mr. Donboli would face severe or extra-judicial treatment upon return, focusing instead on his ability to provide a cover story.
Evidence_Ignored: Risk of excessive or extra-judicial punishment for illegal exit
Legal_Standard: Punishment under a law of general application is not persecution unless it involves excessive or extra-judicial measures.
Application_Factor: Mr. Donboli's illegal exit and failed refugee claim
Decision_Outcome: Judicial review application allowed; case remitted for redetermination by a different panel.
Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation in border documents related to exit and refugee claim

Legal_Provision_Violated: Iranian immigration laws regarding lawful exit
Application_Facts: Mr. Donboli illegally exited Iran and fears persecution upon return.
Misrepresentation_Element: Failed refugee claim and attempt to re-enter Iran after illegal departure
Procedural_Issue: CRDD did not properly assess risk of persecution upon return
Evidence_Used: Details of illegal exit and prior refugee claim
Evidentiary_Deficiency: CRDD failed to consider evidence of potential severe or extra-judicial treatment
Decision_Outcome: CRDD's decision set aside; case remitted for reconsideration
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a Convention refugee
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of refugee claim by a new panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Persecution under the Convention requires more than punishment under a generally applicable law; must involve discriminatory or disproportionate treatment
Decision_Rationale: The risk of persecution must be assessed based on whether punishment for illegal exit would be excessive or applied in a persecutory manner

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Adequate consideration of factors in H&C application
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Insufficient evidence for abuse, credible risk, or hardship
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of evidence exceeding normal expectations

Crimes.Application_Facts: Ms. Pannu overstayed her visa and applied for H&C relief
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over immigration decisions
Evidence_Used: Treatment as divorced woman in India
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Factors considered but not sufficient to meet threshold
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No legal error; decision within acceptable range

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Adequacy of officer’s consideration in H&C refusal
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Alleged ignored evidence not substantiated
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Hardship upon return to home country

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to comply with deportation order
Crimes.Application_Facts: Third H&C application following deportation order
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court review of immigration decisions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Hardship not shown to be unusual or disproportionate
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer reasonably assessed claims
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Exemption from removal on H&C grounds
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Decision rational and within bounds of reasonableness

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Officer’s consideration of H&C factors after work permit expiry
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claims assessed but not sufficient for relief
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of evidence meeting H&C threshold

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Inadmissibility based on membership in an organization
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant's membership in MQM led to inadmissibility determination
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Application denied due to non-compliance with admissibility requirements
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Determination of appropriate procedure for non-disclosure of national security information
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Applicability of section 86 vs. section 87 of IRPA in judicial review
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Tribunal Record with sensitive information subject to redaction
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Non-disclosure motion granted under section 87 of IRPA
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Section 87 of IRPA in conjunction with Federal Courts Rules 317, 318, and Rule 4
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Section 87 aligns better with judicial review context and allows redactions without summaries for national security

Crimes.National_Security_Element: Alleged ties to MQM, designated as a terrorist organization
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Potential threat to national security due to organizational affiliation
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Affiliation with MQM assessed as risk under immigration security grounds
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Membership in an organization linked to terrorism
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Political association alleged to support or be part of a terrorist entity
Crimes.Target_Entity: Canadian immigration and national security system
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Sensitive intelligence-based evidence cited by respondent
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Need to withhold parts of the Tribunal Record for national security reasons
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of inadmissibility based on national security
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Denial of permanent residency and partial non-disclosure of record
